What does this even mean.

What he's probably saying is to remove the age-restriction of the beta programs on Java/Xbox One/Maybe Wins 10? idk, I only use Android.

I use Android which probably has no age-restriction (unless you count Google's account creatiing, for which you have to be 13 and up) as I'm 15 and can play the beta program just fine.

As for some of the other editions (especially Xbox One, I heard), you need to be 17/18 to join the beta program.

This suggestion proposes to remove the age-restriction.

Just to prevent confusion, what he means is this:

If your age on your microsoft account is under 18 and you visit the xbox insider hub to sign up for minecraft betas, you will see something like this:

This is the age limit he means.
Just why? What are you trying to explain here? There's not enough information of why whatever this is should be fixed.
how do

You can sign out of the MS account by going to Settings->Profile and clicking the "Sign out" button.

It's a little different on Windows10 where you have to sign out in the Xbox App (aka "Xbox console companion", which is a separate app from Minecraft).
On windows 10, you can turn off internet and then close out minecraft, and then open it back up. The profile should say "Steve." Then, turn your interntet back on if you need it.

I get your point. Nintendo isn’t related to Xbox servers (which Minecraft uses). The way I see it is: if you don’t pay for the subscription, then your device is basically disconnected from ALL multiplayer internet activities. You can still update and install new games and apps, but it simply doesn’t allow games to go online. It is like this for all games. On the Xbox though, they recently removed the requirement to have Xbox Live to play online for games that are FREE.

Minecraft eRrth!!!

This is a good idea. And it may even push the Bedrock Edition as well. I have a few friends that have recently bought an Xbox. They don't have any interest in Minecraft at the moment. I would love to play it with them, but I prefer Minecraft: Xbox One Edition. For now I don't want to play the Bedrock Edition. If I want to play the Xbox One Edition with them they would have to buy it used on disc. Some of them only want to buy games digitally, some of them only want to buy games new or don't want to search physical stores for it. And there is also the risk that they buy the Bedrock Edition used on a disc. So for now I am not mentioning Minecraft at all to them. If the Xbox One Edition was bundled with the Bedrock Edition I would have recommended Minecraft to them. They then play the Xbox One Edition with me, try the Bedrock Edition and may prefer it. It could even be that they then motivate me to play the Bedrock Edition with them. And if not bundled, then why not included? Why not keep Minecraft: Xbox One Edition alive and make it a console specific game mode in the bedrock edition only available on consoles?
AntVenom (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCK376qNDlNZZDNHsnaWuTeg) suggested this, good to see it's already here.

Now that they pushed bedrock onto ps4 allot of my friends are mad about it the mechanics changed the inventory for creative changed and the overll feel changed just like they did with java and the windows 10 edition give every single person that bought the game before gets a free copy of the other game oke they did that but also keep updating these versions if mojang doesn't do this then I think more and more players that have been playing from the beginning will end up leaving this game alone and never play this again please mojang don't shove bedrock down our troats and force us to play bedrock give us a choice that everyby can be happy with.
PS4 people can play the old version so why not Xbox one and Switch

If any of you have an older version of minecraft for disc on Xbox / PlayStation4, all you have to do is (Read until the end before you do anything) enter the settings, system memory and saved data, and then delete two safe data files and then install the minecraft from the disc (in the next, you have to pull out the disc and delete the minecraft file, I don't know if it works on Xbox but I know it works on PlayStation4)

Here is what might help you:
If you have an iPhone, make sure you use an SD card reader or Realms prior to iPhone transfer, or else all your worlds will be lost. Remember to put all your world files in the SD card or transfer the world using Realms to another Bedrock platform before the iPhone transfer starts.
Once the iPhone transfer is complete, you can transfer your worlds from either the SD card or using the other platform’s Realms subscription back to your iPhone. If you are using the SD card, make sure to use Minecraft’s saves folder.
A similar issue could be if your Switch fails.
ik some dev will not allow this post :)

good idea

As a Java player the one thing I like doing more than anything is to join multiplayer servers created by players who has the freedom to do so. As well as to download any mods made by content creators, commercial or not. I also love doing my own creative works on my private worlds and share my own screenshots with friends.

Now with the new EULA, there are rules that heavily enforces common players, content creators, modifiers and server owners to follow. It completly contradicts the main identity of Minecraft.

 

Just keep in mind that I still am a fan of Minecraft and will always be. Please just take this comment and this post as personal feedback. I just want to do my own thing. Please don't ban me nor the poster.

"With no rules to follow, the choice, it's up to you".

Those mobs are easy to avoid and as though they don't exist anyway. It's accessible for those who want them.

I think the warden should not have been added it is too powerful and there is no way to prevent taking significant damage from it than to simply avoid it, which is impossible when some map/minigame developers add them into the game without the consideration that they're meant to be avoided. Too late to do anything now, I guess, but at least give us more ways to fight it without necessarily resorting to simply avoiding it.
